div.p: In this cartoon commentary on the presidential election of 1864, Union general and Democratic presidential candidate George McClellan is shown holding the lapels of the coats of President Abraham Lincoln, who was then running for re-election on the Republican ticket, and Confederate president Jefferson Davis, apparently in an effort to stop them from fighting. Lincoln, who insists on abolition, and Davis, who insists on separation of the Confederate states from the Union, are each pulling on opposite sides of a map of the United States, tearing it down the middle. This is one of the few cartoons published in the run-up to the 1864 election that is sympathetic to McClellan. In this cartoon, McClellan is depicted as a mature leader who puts the preservation of the United States above all other priorities. In contrast, Lincoln is shown pursuing abolition at the expense of establishing peace, and tearing the country apart in the process.

THE TRUE ISSUE OR "THATS WHATS THE MATTER"."That's What's the Matter" is a pro-Union Civil War song by American folk musician Stephen Foster. The chorus proclaims "That's what's the matter / The rebels have to scatter." Music and lyrics can be accessed at www.civilwarpoetry.org/union/songs/matter.html.

div.head: Map of the United States
div.p: Virginia Virginia is split down the middle as the map tears. During the Civil War, Virginia did indeed split into two states: Confederate Virginia and Unionist West Virginia.
